page.title: 03THE CHURCH
page.content: The modern village has grown up around the Church of All Hallows,which dates back to Norman times.The church tower is 13th century and so is the font.The church also contains some interesting bench ends probably 15th century with panels enclosing shields,some of which have initials,possibly of the occupants of the pews. In one case there is a rare unmutilated scene of the crucifixion. This is believed to be the better of the only two remaining in England. The north aisle,with waggon roof and granite pillarsdates from the early 16th century.It has always been thought that the granite came from Lundy Island.The graveyard contains many interesting stones.
